The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to guarantee that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The approach provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is independent of any particular mathematical structure. It is therefore a step toward a solution of the mathematical foundations problem.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan is enigmatic, and the group is hypothesized to have originated from a close relationship with the cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids. Here, we present the first comparative genomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), is able to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2. Here, we show that the viral accessory protein ORF6 is responsible for this evasion. We show that ORF6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs ORF6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be exploited by other viruses as well. Our findings may provide a basis for the development of new antiviral strategies. Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. Climate change will affect the productivity of staple crops, including maize, which is the main source of calories for the world’s poor. We quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of these countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in ecosystems. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the likely duration of the crisis. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many businesses plan to seek funding through the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly accumulating in convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. This accumulation is mostly in the millimeter size range, which is size-selectively removed by processes yet to be discovered.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most intriguing questions in presolar grain research. The formation of SiC grains in the interiors of AGB stars is not supported by observational data. We present the first evidence for the presence of SiC grains in the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We determined the ages of the grains and found that the majority of the grains are younger than 1 Ga. This is in contrast to theoretical predictions for the ages of the grains. We suggest that the grains were part of aggregates in the interstellar medium and acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides during their time in the interstellar medium. This is the first evidence for the presence of SiC grains in the Murchison CM2 meteorite.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

Reproductive output is a fundamental measure of the success of a species. Here, we show that the increase in reproductive output in domesticated animals and in species that practice allonursing is due to an increase in metabolic power rather than an increase in resource availability. We also show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. This suggests that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This finding has important implications for understanding the evolution of reproduction and the evolution of domestication. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of allonursing in animals. Finally, it has implications for understanding the evolution of reproduction in humans. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we present an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cell clusters that are responsible for sensing and integrating multiple lines of information. This paper describes the nature of the communication network between these clusters. The network is surprisingly effective at transmitting information and is particularly effective at transmitting information between clusters. The network is also surprisingly small-world, which means that the network is both efficient at transmitting information locally and globally. This paper provides a unique perspective on the nature of the communication network between cells. It also provides a unique perspective on the nature of the communication network between blood vessels.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for informing public health policy. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information is often not available in a timely manner. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate how the data can be used to track the pandemic, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. The selectivity filter is closed in the closed state and opens upon channel activation. This allosteric coupling is mediated by the activation gate. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and that its substitution with Alanine leads to a lack of C-type inactivation gating and an inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This finding has important implications for the understanding of the closed state and the design of new drugs. It also has implications for the design of new ion channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microorganisms that reside in the digestive tract of animals. The composition of the microbiome is important for the health of the host animal. The gut microbiome is also dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can change over time. The composition of the microbiome can be altered by the host animal, and the microbiome can also alter the host animal. The host animal can also alter the microbiome. This study investigated the potential of anaerobic fungi to alter the microbiome. The anaerobic fungi were shown to synthesize a variety of natural products that could be used as therapeutics. These results support the use of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products.

Anxiety is a major risk factor for social disorders, yet the underlying mechanisms remain unclear. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens, a brain region involved in social behavior. We further show that high-anxious rats are less likely to become dominant in a dyadic contest and that microinfusion of mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduces social rank. Finally, we demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious rats. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the aging process. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal tissues and upregulated in adult tissues. We also show that IGF2BP1 can reprogram hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the aging process. This mechanism may also be relevant to hemoglobin disorders. This mechanism may also be relevant to the hemoglobin system in other species.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. Despite the use of chemotherapy, the survival rate of cancer patients remains low. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Furthermore, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure. The major drugs for treating hypertension are angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin II receptor blockers, and calcium channel blockers. Calcium channel blockers are the most widely used drugs for treating hypertension. However, the mechanisms of action of these drugs are not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate STIM/ORAI-mediated Ca2+ entry in vascular smooth muscle cells. Our data indicate caution against the use of calcium channel blockers in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of calcium channel blockers action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that calcium channel blockers promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of calcium channel blockers in the treatment of cardiovascular remodeling. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but not in older forests. The NWFP’s success in halting the decline of early-seral bird populations is explained by the fact that early-seral ecosystems are stable and bird populations are increasing. However, the NWFP has not yet reversed the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is therefore a major challenge for the pharmaceutical industry. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We show that our approach is successful in identifying compounds with high activity against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best compound identified by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic. This compound is also more accessible, has higher solubility, and exhibits better membrane permeability than telithromycin. Thus, our approach can be used to identify new antibiotics with improved properties. This approach can be applied to other antibiotic classes as well. We expect that our approach will help to reduce the time and cost of drug development.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply the networks in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this practice has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the amount of sleep. These effects may have important implications for performance, health, and safety.

One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the Younger Dryas cooling at ∼12.9 ka. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the Younger Dryas boundary (YDB). The role of cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen-4 (CTLA-4) in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital CTLA-4–deficient mice. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice resulted in lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of CD4+Foxp3+ Treg cells. However, T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to adoptively transfer the diseases into T cell-deficient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Thus, CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its function is context-dependent. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetle diversity was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of plant-feeding insects and the evolution of plant cell walls. They also have implications for our understanding of the evolution of the terrestrial environment and the origin of agriculture. (Show more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. The development of new vaccines and treatments is a long and expensive process. Therefore, it is important to develop methods to improve the effectiveness of existing treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to improve the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our results show that our approach can improve the neutralizing activity of this antibody by ∼10- to 600-fold against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) risk. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate AD pathogenesis by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE4 accelerates the accumulation of a protein, C1q, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies also suggest that APOE may be a potential therapeutic target for AD. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that APOE2 reduces the accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses. Thus, APOE may be a potential therapeutic target for AD.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 2,300 km, which is the deepest part of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of the liquid iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. This study provides a new perspective on the inner core formation by showing that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available. The drug’s effects on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to have negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the drug’s effects on the individual’s behavior.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also unique in the brain: Language processing is the only cognitive process in which the neural and computational mechanisms are not yet fully understood. Here, we show that the most powerful machine learning models for natural language processing also predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain. This finding provides computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. It also suggests that the brain may use predictive processing to solve the language modeling problem, in which it must infer the next word in a sequence given the previous words. This finding may have implications for understanding the brain’s computational mechanisms in general.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific fields. However, it is still unclear whether DL is a good choice for scientific computing. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors. One of the most prominent is the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This is supposedly a result of the “exponential gap” between the number of people who can understand and the number who cannot. This gap is said to be caused by a lack of understanding of the underlying mathematics. Here, we show that this gap is a myth.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. We sequenced the genome of a patient from Mexico, where the disease is endemic, and compared it with that of the leprosy pathogen from India. The genomes are similar in size and synteny, and have lost 50% of their genes through pseudogenization. The two pathogens are still closely related, and may be the result of a single speciation event. This suggests that the disease has persisted for millions of years. The results have implications for the evolution of the human genome and the origin of leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and statistical mechanics. However, the relation between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in isolated quantum systems is captured by a statistical ensemble with a specific amount of entropy, which is the accumulated entanglement during the dynamics. This result is a consequence of the integrability of the system, which allows for a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of the time. Our result has important implications for the study of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral proteins. In contrast, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development is the COVI-VAC vaccine. We show that the vaccine is highly attenuated, resulting in reduced lung pathology and weight loss in hamsters. In addition, the vaccine protects hamsters from all SARS-CoV-2 variants tested so far. The large-scale manufacturing potential of the vaccine makes it a promising candidate for mass vaccination programs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been responsible for the deaths of millions of people in the past. Today, plague is rare in Europe, but it was a major killer in the past. The bacterium that causes plague, Yersinia pestis, can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways, including the inhalation of infectious droplets by humans and rodents. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice, were the primary vectors of plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This finding challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known story, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is not. This study fills this gap by reconstructing the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. Here we show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Thus, TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the major cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic structures that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is controlled by the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. However, how ADF/cofilin proteins sever actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension has no effect on cofilin binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon cofilin binding. We propose that this ADF/cofilin-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East, suggesting a recent arrival of the Malagasy people. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. This article is protected by copyright. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion. This work also suggests that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The ribosome reads the sequence of the mRNA to determine the amino acid sequence of the nascent polypeptide. The presence of mRNA modifications can have a profound impact on translation. In this study, we show that the presence of a common modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNAs can have a significant impact on translation, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in the course of translating mRNAs. This study provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on translation and may have implications for understanding the function of Ψ in the context of mRNA translation. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to a range of potential confounds, and longitudinal analyses indicate that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with positive changes in a wide range of outcomes over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. Here, we use a quantitative approach to test the hypothesis that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. This result is consistent with energetic constraints on body size imposed by the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The cold temperature of the nasal cavity is a major factor in the initiation of the cold virus common cold. However, the mechanism by which the cold temperature of the nasal cavity inhibits the growth of cold viruses is not well understood. Here, we show that the cold temperature of the nasal cavity inhibits the growth of cold viruses by reducing the antiviral response of infected cells. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanism of the cold temperature of the nasal cavity in the initiation of the cold virus common cold. It also provides a basis for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of the cold virus common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of sensing systems to respond to environmental signals. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect contact with surfaces. This mechanism requires attachment of type IV pili to a solid surface, followed by pili retraction and signal transduction through the Chp chemosensory system, a chemotaxis-like sensory system that regulates cAMP production and transcription of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. These findings demonstrate that type IV pili can be used as a sensor for surface-specific attachment, and that the mechanical activity of pili can be used as a signal for regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanism may be important for the survival of P. aeruginosa in the environment and in the host. Understanding how bacteria use pili for sensing and signaling may provide insights into the regulation of surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This knowledge may also be useful for the development of new strategies for controlling this important pathogen. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. However, the role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is poorly understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in the blood of free-living white-tailed deer. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ plaques and cell death. Here, we show that neurons are also involved in the early stages of AD, and that they produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. We identify an inflammatory profile unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, since neighboring glial cells did not express similar molecules. Moreover, we demonstrate within disease-vulnerable regions of the human brain that a neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede insoluble Aβ plaque and tau tangle formation. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the role of the immune system in AD, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Hellenistic period. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The cellular concentration of dinucleoside tetraphosphates, often described as alarmones, increases in response to stress. The predominant enzyme responsible for decapping those RNAs, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable alarmones to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes N-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes N-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The immune dysfunction observed in sepsis is associated with the emergence of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and regulatory T cells (Treg). We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is the main component of the global carbon cycle. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet, with plants (≈450 Gt C) being primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our analysis reveals that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state, even though no external forcing is applied. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is used in many applications, including cutting tools, surgical tools, and jewelry. However, diamond is brittle and is easily damaged by external forces. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, without phonon instability, by applying a large strain. This opens up new possibilities for diamond applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The structure of the peptide was largely disordered and highly dynamic. It exhibited a unique structural architecture with one four-residue α-helix and one three-residue antiparallel β-sheet stabilized by two disulfide bonds. The antifungal activity was associated with the peptide binding to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings, followed by penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli. This work illustrates the structural basis for antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental unit of evolution. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of Drosophila sperm during their posttesticular life history. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also demonstrate that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome following mating and sperm storage in the female reproductive tract. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the proteome dynamics of sperm during their posttesticular life history and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be useful for understanding the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions in other species. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping them stick to the vessel wall and control bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that platelets and VWF in the blood are in a state of continuous change, switching between two states with different binding properties. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. We also show that force can switch VWF to a second state with faster binding, which explains the effects of VWD mutations on bleeding. This mechanism may be important in other diseases. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study because of the small number of viruses compared with bacteria. This study provides a comprehensive catalog of human-associated viruses, with a focus on the impact of the virome on human health. The catalog is available as a database and as a curated, searchable, and navigable web application. The database contains over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. The database is used to show that the human virome is associated with disease. The database is available at https://www.humanvirome.org/.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of the surface environment has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface environment in turn is influenced by the temperature of the surface environment in the past. Thus, the temperature of the surface environment in the past can be inferred from the temperature of the surface environment in the present. This principle is demonstrated here using a method based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes.

Potassium channels are important for the regulation of many physiological processes. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks an intracellular activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the regulation of K+ channel gating and inactivation. They also suggest that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings may also provide a basis for the development of new drugs for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. (Show more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This is a major change in our current understanding of the invasion process.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following influenza challenge. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may inform the development of strategies to mitigate influenza-associated morbidity and mortality. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power. This increase is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More importantly, the merge operation is implemented by multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions, providing initial evidence for a neural implementation of the merge operation postulated by linguists. Our results suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be essential for language comprehension.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is one of the two essential scaffolds in the pathway. We show here that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We also show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation may be used in tissue-specific regulation.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve nitrogen fixation in agricultural settings, and could also be applied to other nitrogen-fixing systems, such as cyanobacteria in water treatment plants. The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and it is being rapidly deforested. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to incentivize community patrols, but the effectiveness of these programs is unknown. We study a community monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to sense the presence and location of sound sources in their environment. The hearing organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the animal’s body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s hearing is outsourced to its web, which acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can hear without a body and can increase its hearing surface area enormously. This provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can reduce the excess mortality rate by 3.61 million per year, and the total excess mortality by 5.55 million per year. This would be accompanied by a 10–70% increase in rainfall over densely populated regions in India and 10–30% over northern China, and by a 10–40% increase in rainfall over Central America, West Africa, and the Sahel, thus contributing to water and food security. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil fuels is needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results highlight the importance of air pollution in the assessment of climate change. COVID-19 is a pandemic that has killed over 500,000 people in the United States alone. The current vaccines are effective, but their production costs are high. This work describes a strategy to reduce the cost of manufacturing the vaccine by using a variant of the spike protein that is easier to manufacture and has better binding to the ACE2 receptor. This strategy could be used to reduce the cost of manufacturing vaccines for other diseases.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in the development of many tissues. In the past few years, we have identified secreted small ALKAL proteins (FAM150s) as ligands for human ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and ALKALs are involved in zebrafish pigment pattern formation. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. This study provides insights into the role of ALK/LTK family receptors in development and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of the plague pathogen Yersinia pestis is one of the most dramatic examples of its impact. The emergence of plague is shrouded in mystery, and the available evidence is based on a small number of genomes. Here, we present 17 genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the evolution of plague during this critical period. We find that plague spread rapidly across Eurasia, and the emergence of the plague pathogen was not a one-time event but rather a process that took place over millennia. This study provides a more complete picture of the formative years of plague. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. However, the management practices that can maximize SOC storage on grassland-derived Mollisols remain uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. However, these practices did not significantly increase SOC storage in perennial pastures. These results highlight the key role of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to rank the spillover potential of 887 viruses from animals. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery and surveillance efforts, and we made the framework and data available as a web tool, SpillOver. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as an indicator of the reward’s nutritional value. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in plants. This work provides insight into the evolution of a convergent trait in two vertebrate-visited plants.

The genetic structure of Europe is a major topic of current research. However, the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change is poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our results indicate that they originated from southeastern Europe and that they differed genetically from men. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique insight into the mechanism of lagging strand synthesis and the role of pol δ in DNA replication. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be replicated by RNA polymerases, but the activity of RNA polymerases is poorly understood. Here, we report the development of a highly active RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA molecules from an RNA template. This polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the polymerase can replicate genetic information and convert it into functional molecules. This work provides a significant step toward the development of an in vitro RNA world. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in other cities and other types of urban features. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

COVID-19 is a highly contagious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment of COVID-19 is still in the stage of clinical trial. Tocilizumab, a monoclonal antibody against interleukin 6, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It can reduce the mortality rate and shorten the hospital stay.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) is known to be inducible by iron starvation, but the role of the BGC in copper homeostasis has not been explored. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC is inducible by copper, and that the secreted isocyanide products bind copper and impact intracellular copper pools. The copper-chelating properties of xan BGC isocyanides support a role for these products in mediating interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the evolution of fungal metal homeostasis and the role of natural products in mediating interactions with competing microbes. (Show more)

Frost damage is a major threat to agriculture, forestry, and animal husbandry. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are changing in response to frost damage.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which retains a predominantly IL-17A+ phenotype and is required for the development of colitis, whereas the other subset, which expresses IFN-γ, is dispensable for colitis development. These results indicate that Th17 cells can have opposing roles in the development of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to these subsets will be critical for the development of therapeutic strategies to treat inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms underlying the disease are not fully understood. Here, we report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify potential therapies. This method will also enable disease modeling and identification of disease mechanisms. This will lead to the development of better therapies for ALS. This will improve the quality of life of ALS patients. This method will also help to understand the mechanisms of other neurodegenerative diseases.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in pathogen transmission. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector hosts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the transmission of Anaplasma to vertebrate hosts. We also show that antifreeze glycoprotein alters the permeability of the gut barrier and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, two critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vector hosts. They also suggest that targeting the microbiota of vector hosts may represent a promising approach for controlling vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the origin and diversification of birds. However, the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group is poorly understood due to a lack of fossils. Here, we report a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases our understanding of the early evolution of the short-tailed bird group and the origin of the modern avian tail.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This finding has implications for the interpretation of observations of stratospheric water vapor, which have been used to argue for a strong climate sensitivity. It also has implications for the design of climate experiments in the stratosphere. Finally, it has implications for the interpretation of observations of the tropical tropopause, which have been used to argue for a strong tropical tropopause feedback. This finding has implications for the design of climate experiments in the tropical tropopause region. [Read more]

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of a vertebrate can be modified by pigments, such as carotenoids, or by the color of its bones, which are blue-green in many species. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. We show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans, and that the color of the animals is controlled by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is present in the blood of vertebrates. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for crypsis in green foliage even under near-infrared light. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common feature of solid tumors, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes tumorigenesis are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on messenger RNA. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the hypoxia-inducible factors HIF-1α and HIF-2α. ALKBH5 expression is required for hypoxia-induced enrichment of breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs), which are responsible for initiating tumor growth. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is required for the hypoxic phenotype, and may represent a therapeutic target for cancer treatment. This study provides insight into the role of m6A modification in cancer biology. It also provides a mechanism by which hypoxia may promote tumorigenesis. Finally, it provides a rationale for the use of ALKBH5 inhibitors in cancer therapy. This study may also provide a rationale for the use of ALKBH5 inhibitors in cancer therapy.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fin

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This age model will also establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a role in various biological processes, including cancer, metabolism, and circadian rhythm. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
