The spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in circulating variants. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion. This work provides insight into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure of the spike protein and may inform the development of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can release large amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. However, the effects of climate change on wildfire activity are highly uncertain. We show that human ignitions can have a large influence on future fire regimes, and that these effects can offset some of the warming caused by greenhouse gas emissions. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the climate system and the need to better understand the interactions between climate, fire, and carbon in the future.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth and health of their microbial partners. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which is required for the maintenance of a normal symbiont population level. Finally, catabolism of the glycan by the symbiont is also required for a periodic acidification of the host crypts, which increases the level of oxygen available to the symbionts and enhances their capacity to produce bioluminescence at night. This study provides a mechanism by which animals may regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. Motivated by known patterns in suicide and homicide by gender and recent research on gender biases in semantic space, we identify the gender bias of our topics (e.g., a topic about pain medication is feminine). We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identity of the putative reservoirs of the bacterium Yersinia pestis, which causes plague, is still debated. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were strongly correlated, and that these fluctuations preceded the outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that the bacterium was repeatedly introduced into European harbors from Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. However, they are also a food source for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, asteroids have recently experienced an extensive outbreak of wasting disease. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease in asteroids.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults. Despite advances in therapy, the prognosis of AML patients is poor. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. Here, we show that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. Furthermore, we show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can also inhibit the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Thus, our study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of AML. This approach could be used to treat AML patients with a high expression of IL1RAP. The results also provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East, suggesting a recent arrival of the Malagasy people. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, a unique island in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase. We found that the RNA also encodes a second protein (denoted AzuR) that competes with the RNA for binding to the cadA and galE promoters. The translation and base-pairing functions compete for the same binding site. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate multiple genes. This is the first example of a dual-function RNA that has evolved to regulate two genes involved in carbon utilization. This dual-function RNA is widespread in bacteria. The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. The development of new vaccines and treatments is a long and expensive process. Therefore, it is important to develop methods that can help improve the effectiveness of existing treatments. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach that can be used to improve the neutralizing activity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our approach can be used to identify mutations that can improve the binding affinity of antibodies against variants. This approach can potentially be used to improve the effectiveness of existing antibodies and can potentially be used to develop new antibodies for variants.

Crop experts are the first line of defense in the early detection of crop anomalies. However, their assessments are subjective and often qualitative, making it difficult to use them in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We also discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the CPC survey is a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural monitoring systems. This work provides a framework for the use of crop expert assessments in quantitative agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The plastid genome is a unique genomic element that has been shaped by the evolutionary transition of photosynthetic organisms from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step towards quantifying the risk of future droughts in SSA. However, the model resolution is still too coarse to precisely quantify the changing likelihood of extreme droughts. This will require the development of high-resolution climate models. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal provides a link between the discovery of naturally occurring quasicrystals and the development of nuclear weapons.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is characterized by the activation of microglia and astrocytes, which produce proinflammatory mediators. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. ASK1-deficient microglia exhibited reduced neuroinflammation, suggesting ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1-deficient glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in MS. Further, we propose that ASK1-deficient glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation in other neurodegenerative diseases. This study provides insights into the roles of ASK1 in the glial cells and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California. Continued warming will increase the probability of drought, and thus will exacerbate the impacts of this extreme weather. Our findings have important implications for water resources management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk in California and elsewhere in the world. They also highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the current and future occurrence of drought.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. Mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, but that individual-level variation in responsiveness is considerable. This variation may help explain the prevalence of negative news content around the world. It may also help explain the tendency for news seeking to be predominantly negative.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 or ORAI1 cause Stormorken syndrome. We show that the mutations in STIM1 result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and that the mutations in ORAI1 result in reduced inactivation of the CRAC channel. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. The mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active endocytosis. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases. They also provide a platform for studying the role of endocytosis in the spread of aggregates in other diseases. This could lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral diseases. Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways supporting cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-derived carbon unit. We report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of both human serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1 and 2 (SHMT1/2). The inhibitor is effective in inhibiting SHMT in cancer cells, and in particular, in blocking the growth of a particularly sensitive cancer cell-line screen of B-cell malignancies. We also show that one of the few metabolic consequences of SHMT inhibition is increased formate utilization, which paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cell lines. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, and thus represents a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The SHMT inhibitor is a promising lead for the development of a cancer therapeutic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. The disease is characterized by the presence of intracellular inclusions containing a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals are a promising platform for quantum simulation of many-body states, including topological states, and for quantum information processing. The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants. The Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event is thought to have eliminated many groups of plants, including the dinosaurs. However, the Cretaceous is also a time of great plant diversification. This research focuses on a group of plants that are thought to have diversified in a dark forest habitat. The research presented here suggests that these plants were aquatic.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are responsible for a number of diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 thousand years ago, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the human-specific genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising because of climate change. This study provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise, which is higher than previous estimates. This higher rate is consistent with the rate of sea level rise predicted by climate models. This study also provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise that can be used to update climate projections.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America today, but that pain has also increased with age in midlife in other wealthy countries. This suggests that the erosion of working-class life in America is not just a problem of income inequality, but also of health inequality.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The study of the mechanisms of enzymes is often aided by the use of NMR spectroscopy, which can provide information about the structure and dynamics of the enzyme–substrate complex. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the mechanism of a pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzyme, tryptophan synthase. The study of this enzyme is important because it is a defining example of a reaction in enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe and often fatal disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, effectively inhibited MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV) replication in vitro, and showed efficacy against Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV in a mouse model. Prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provided a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of nature. However, the timing and source of these nutrients are often unknown. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan to a luminescent symbiont in a squid is strategically timed to enhance the persistence of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which in turn modulates the pH of the habitat, enhancing the luminescence of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the immune-microbial symbiosis of animals. It also suggests that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general feature of animal-microbe interactions. (Show more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The intervention was a brief, online training that encouraged teachers to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. The intervention halved suspension rates in a randomized field experiment. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of DNA. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. For the N3-EtdT lesion that disrupts base pairing, multiple transcriptional lesion bypass routes were found. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) proteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be cleaved sequentially by cell-surface proteases, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. Here, we show that the first cleavages are significant for virus infection, because they allow virions to resist cell-receptor-induced conformational changes, which restrict the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first cleavages are significant for MERS-CoV virulence, because they expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection. Therefore, the first cleavages may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV pathogenesis. Thus, understanding how the first cleavages contribute to CoV infection may help to explain why MERS-CoV causes severe disease in humans. This knowledge may also help to develop more effective vaccines and antiviral agents. © 2016 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. Changing the diets of the population is one of the most important levers for reducing these impacts. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a university cafeteria can have a large impact on meal selection without increasing overall sales. This suggests that simple changes to catering practices could have a major impact on population health and the environment. Our results have implications for the design of interventions to promote more sustainable and healthier diets. They also suggest that the physical environment in which people make decisions can be a powerful lever for promoting behavior change. This has implications for the design of interventions to promote sustainable consumption more generally.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is a rich source of information about the cell’s biology. Here we use a combination of methods to study the surfaceome of a breast epithelial cell line stably expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a first step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer biology and drug discovery.

The 2020 presidential election will be the first in US history in which the entire electorate will be able to vote by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The SARS-CoV-2 virus has been responsible for the majority of these deaths. The SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein ORF8 is a rapidly evolving protein that has been proposed to interfere with the host immune response. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 at 2.04-Å resolution. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This unique interface may be responsible for immune suppression and evasion. This structure will aid in the development of future antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic-induced release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cortex to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia. They also suggest that the CRF system may be a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypoxia. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is full of associations. We are interested in finding the strongest ones. Unfortunately, we can only search for the strongest associations. This means that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant an association that we find. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

Here, we report the generation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells by using a single transcription factor, Ets variant 2 (ETV2). This method provides a promising approach for the generation of ECs for the treatment of vascular disorders and the formation of vascular networks for the regeneration of damaged organs. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important mediators of cancer development. Here, we report the discovery of two physiological ligands for Alk and Ltk, augmentor-α1 and augmentor-α2 (also named “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively). We show that these ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore patterning. We also demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for zebrafish iridophore development and that they do so by activating Ltk and not Alk. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands are required for the development of a particular type of sensory cells in zebrafish. This work provides insights into the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well established, the molecular bases of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency impaired β-cell function and insulin secretion, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses. The avian influenza viruses are divided into three subtypes, A/chicken/bird/etc. (H5N1), A/chicken/bird/etc. (H7N7), and A/chicken/bird/etc. (H7N9). The H5N1 subtype is the most dangerous, as it can easily jump to humans. The molecular details of the packaging of the viral genome into the viral particles are unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. It might also lead to the development of new antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process involving multiple factors. The present study demonstrates that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a major threat to human life, property, and ecosystems. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes in other cities and other types of urban features. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides insights into the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the evolution of arthropod–plant interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to severe birth defects and neurological complications. The current outbreak has led to a global concern for the safety of pregnant women. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. However, treatment given 2 d postinfection is mostly ineffective in accelerating plasma viral load loss. These results can help guide the development of effective antiviral treatment strategies for pregnant women. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a major stressor for coral reefs, but the underlying causes are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host increases during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont subsequently promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the organism from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to systemic infections. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn can promote tumor growth. Our study identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of the microbiome in cancer and for developing strategies to control tumor growth. They also provide a model for studying the role of the microbiome in host–microbe homeostasis and regenerative responses. Finally, they highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may result in the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in global assessments of ecosystem services. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. At the same time, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In mammals, however, the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating, and the only known mechanism for regeneration in the adult CNS is through the sprouting of preformed axons. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in C. elegans that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for discovering genes involved in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the adult CNS may be more plastic than previously thought, and that the ability to regenerate may be more widespread than previously appreciated. Recombination is the process by which DNA is broken and then rewired. It is essential for the proper development of all multicellular organisms. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is concentrated in hotspots, interspersed with cold regions. The hotspots are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice. This suggests that the mechanisms of recombination described here in Mimulus may be ancient and conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing only a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that the dominant component of metabolic fluctuations in the resting brain is topographically similar to the default mode network (DMN), a network of regions that is highly active during rest. In Parkinson’s disease (PD), the dominant component of metabolic fluctuations was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic fluctuations in cerebral blood flow. Network deactivation was reduced in early PD, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Time-course comparisons of DMN loss in longitudinal resting metabolic scans from PD and Alzheimer’s disease subjects illustrated that significant reductions appeared later for PD, in parallel with the development of cognitive dysfunction. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. In bacteria, the best studied modification is the 5′ addition of nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to transfer RNAs. In this study, we describe a 5′ modification in yeast, which we call nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA. We show that NAD+ RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that NAD+ RNA is produced cotranscriptionally. These results define an additional 5′ RNA cap structure in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This modification may be important in the regulation of mitochondrial gene expression. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in whole blood and monocytes persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These epigenetic alterations are associated with glycemia and support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of metabolic memory and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes. Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, suggesting that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile organic compounds. Many of these compounds are nitrogenous, meaning that they contain nitrogen. The biosynthetic pathways for many of these nitrogenous volatiles are unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene is required for the production of other nitrogenous compounds in Nicotiana benthamiana, providing a proof-of-concept for the use of this gene in the production of other nitrogenous volatiles in plants. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and lays the foundation for the development of improved varieties with enhanced flavor. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. They also highlight the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming in the design of effective conservation and management strategies. This is particularly important in light of the current global biodiversity crisis.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial memory. The neurons in MEC are organized into different types, which are thought to be involved in different aspects of spatial processing. However, the anatomical and functional organization of these cell types is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that the grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a grid map of space, are anatomically distinct from other cell types. This study provides a new method for studying the organization of neurons in the brain. It will be useful for understanding the function of the brain.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. Here, we describe a unique type of synapse between striosomes and dopamine-containing dendrites in the nigrostriatal system. These striosome–dendron bouquets are highly specialized, with striosomal fibers tightly intertwined with dopamine-containing dendrites and with other neurons and glia. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent critical integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other predicted how connected they felt. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN automaticity is governed by a combination of voltage-gated currents and Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SANCs and is required for maintaining the SR Ca2+ content in SANCs. In addition, we show that STIM1 regulates the electrical activity of SANCs by modulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry and L-type Ca2+ current. These findings reveal a role for STIM1 in the regulation of SAN automaticity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant defense against insect herbivory has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance against the rice leaffolder in rice plants, which is associated with increased levels of jasmonic acid (JA) and Si, and enhanced expression of defense genes. These results suggest that Si and JA may interact in plant defense against insect herbivory. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may help to develop Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. Furthermore, we show that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our results provide a basis for further studies on the role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in lipid metabolism and macrophage activation. Language is a complex system that relies on the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This mechanism is distinct from the conventional view of language processing, which relies on the storage of information in persistent activity. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds. Thus, they rely on a variety of defense mechanisms to protect themselves from pathogens. One of the major defense mechanisms is the production of siRNAs, which are then used to silence the expression of pathogen-related genes. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiencies. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful in the field of agriculture and biotechnology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a major threat to coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small tributaries has been overlooked in many studies, despite their ubiquity. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system that is biased toward rare configurations of its degrees of freedom. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems that are biased toward rare configurations of their degrees of freedom. We also discuss the implications of our results for the design of thermodynamic machines.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients with autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of the cortex, leading to changes in the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that these changes can be used to explain the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. These findings offer mechanistic insights into the circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the presence of NMDAR-Abs may be a useful biomarker for the prediction of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This could have important implications for the clinical management of patients with autoimmune encephalitis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key topic in Earth system science. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the lack of proxy data and modeling approaches that can capture the full complexity of the Earth system. Here, we present a new approach to study abrupt climate change. We show that a major climate perturbation occurred during a glacial period and that the perturbation was linked to an increase in atmospheric CO2 and anoxia. This approach can be applied to study other abrupt climate change events. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in oil palm plantations. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification may be a useful tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm, but that it is not a panacea.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins, vesicles, and other molecules from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and other organelles. The exocytosis process is regulated by a complex network of proteins. The exocyst complex is one of the key regulators of the exocytosis process. In this study, we discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocytosis process and offers a potential target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual can have a profound effect on its fitness. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, resulting in two sexes. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, however, sex determination is polygenic, resulting in more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two sex determination alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the evolution or introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner creates additional axes of phenotypic variation. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Understanding the genetic basis of sex determination is critical for predicting the effects of anthropogenic change on the evolution of sex.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, a class of oxidized carotenoids, that are formed by the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. These adducts are formed by the photodegradation of the lipofuscin pigment in the retinal pigment epithelium. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the oxidation and degradation of bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the intracellular levels of iron may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease. (Show more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization is one of the most important processes in ecology and evolution. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, because predators become specialized, and then they become adapted to their prey type, and then they become specialized on other prey types. We show that this evolutionary process is not a dead end, and that predators can evolve into new prey types. This process is driven by the evolution of specialized structures, and the evolution of specialization between these structures and prey type.

The evolution of the human hand is one of the most important topics in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is incomplete, however, and the origin of some of the key derived features of the modern human hand is unclear. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key derived feature of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways supporting cell growth is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway, which converts serine to glycine and a folate-derived carbon unit. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), a key enzyme in this pathway. We show that these inhibitors are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell malignancies. We also show that one of the inhibitors is uniquely effective in a lymphoma cell line that is deficient in glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma cells that can be targeted therapeutically. This work provides a rationale for targeting the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway in cancer. This pathway is a promising target for cancer therapy, and our work provides a starting point for the development of such agents. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of one-carbon unit inhibitors as cancer therapeutics.

The world is facing a food crisis, and the agricultural sector is the main driver of this crisis. However, the agricultural sector is also responsible for the loss of biodiversity and the degradation of natural resources. This study shows that forests can be a source of food and nutrition security, and that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting food and nutrition security goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to subsoil compaction. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has propagated subsoil compaction into deeper soil layers, exceeding safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
